job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Work with very smart, mission-driven people. UNC has been investing additional funds for workforce development for its own employees, and if you have a great supportive manager, you will enjoy working here. Good retirement options (State TSERS pension available as an option)
cons:
Pay. Pay raises and the pay bands are dictated by the state legislature. The difference between the expected salary (if COL was fully adjusted) and the current salaries, mean it is unaffordable for most UNC employees to live in the same town we work in (Chapel Hill). Most UNC employees commute from elsewhere, but bear in mind that all Triangle towns are becoming more unaffordable over time (rent and home prices).

Your experience and mileage will vary, depending on your manager and departmental culture. These aspects will dictate your experience at UNC. If you have a great manager, stick around and enjoy! If you don't, consider applying externally elsewhere, or wait a year and apply internally to a new position at UNC.

job_title: Senior Systems Administrator/IT Manager in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: The University Environment offers a lot of flexibility, job related training (for certifications etc.) and has a generally relaxed atmosphere. Benefits are decent and easy to access. They are generally a steady employer being one of the larger Universities in the South East if you're not working on a grant funded project as your only role.
cons: Compensation is below Average though Flexibility is Above Average. Parking is very complicated and can be very expensive for an employee (~$500/yr or more - if you can get it - would be considered a deal). Benefits are Average. Funding for IT equipment / licensing etc. is below average, cumbersome and often fraught with Politics and Red Tape. Many groups are understaffed and/or under-skilled due to the lower compensation rates so attracting talent to your team / group can be challenging. Group-level Management is typically decent however High Level leadership does not put enough value on employees in general nor the health of the many smaller business units that UNC spawns. These groups are grant based and as such can loose their funding - ask about the funding source for any role you may consider. UNC employees are subjected to End of year Gov shutdowns which can leave you without pay during holidays etc.. Career Advancement is slow, typically someone has to leave or retire for a potential position to open up and there will be internal and external competition for such openings.

job_title: Student Services Specialist in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: The benefits are decent, and it's nice to be a part of the campus community.
cons:
During the 10 years that I've worked for UNC, I've held a variety of positions in different departments. Conservatively, I would say that at least half of Student Services staff are severely overworked and underpaid at UNC, though staff experiences will certainly vary by department. Broadly, UNC prioritizes the hiring of upper level admin, while deprioritizing the hiring of low-level staff that allow UNC to function. We have WAY MORE provosts, deans, directors, etc. than we did when I was undergrad here and much fewer full-time staff positions. Post-pandemic, UNC decided to increase admissions without hiring additional low-level staff AND in spite of existing classroom shortages (student services staff are partially responsible for finding classrooms to schedule courses and events-- this is a significant part of the job), meaning student services jobs are getting more difficult. Like most people who work in education, my most absurd responsibility is to put a band-aid on problems that are actually systemic to the University with little to no assistance or resources. 

Administratively, UNC is a dumpster fire. This was true prior to the pandemic, but COVID really shined a light on a lot of their dysfunction. If you decide to take a student services job, you will definitively be impacted by their decision-making. If you're lucky enough to have a good chair and department manager, admin's negative impact on staff will be somewhat ameliorated but that's a big IF and realistically, there's only so much that individual departments can do in that respect. 

If you have no choice and decide to take a student services position, keep your resume and references up-to-date so you can quickly apply for other jobs once you hit your limit.

Side note: avoid a low-level job with the Registrar at all costs. I work closely with folks in that department, and they too seem to be horrendously overworked.

Side note 2: Be very wary of the one-line positive reviews for UNC on this site. I find them to be highly suspicious given what I now of campus-wide staff burnout and frustration.

job_title: Manager in Chapel Hill, NC
pros:
(This review is only speaking for the UNC Kenan-Flagler Business School, not UNC as a whole.)
Most colleagues were pleasant and team-oriented, and many were passionate about their jobs, willing to help colleagues, and smart/good at their jobs.
I had a great manager who allowed and encouraged personal and professional development, even if it meant being flexible with work hours.
Staff at K-F are typically paid more than staff on other parts of UNC's campus. 
Usually not expected to work over 40 hours/week, except for special events.
Hard work is recognized and appreciated by senior managers.
As a relatively young employee, I found that if you are willing to work hard and take on new projects, you can learn new things and grow without having to take a new job - a great way to build new skills and add to your resume.
cons:
During my time there, it was difficult for staff to get raises due to budget concerns.
It can be hard to move up quickly, especially in programs with a small staff, since people tend to stay in their jobs for a long time and you can't move up unless someone leaves.
There can be tricky HR concerns when trying to move up within the organization due to UNC's career banding, which can result in less compensation.

review_title: Classic Government Job; Pros and Cons
job_title: Admissions Counselor in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Very low expectations for performing high quality work.  You can easily manage a light schedule and spend a lot of time socializing.  Opportunities for a wide variety of events and job tasks, as well as travel, can keep things fresh when there is work to do.  Amazing co-workers who are brilliant people and make going to work a pleasure.
cons: Moving up has nothing to do with your abilities.  It's all about how long you've been there and if you tow the line.  Compensation is government level, so if you are up high it's massive compared to your actual work load; more of the opposite at the bottom.  You get paid to put in the years, not to put out results.  More focus is placed on political sensitivity and identity politics than actually doing what is right or delivering a high-standard service. There are so many bizarre, made-up, politically-correct boundaries that even the most eager feel distraught.

review_title: Lots of Knowledge, but lacking Wisdom.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chapel Hill, NC
pros:
The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill is an interesting place to work. The campus has a wide variety of opportunities for employment, education, and growth. Most of the supporting staff and faculty are extremely dedicated and concern for the welfare of the educational mission of the University and the students placed in their care.
• The positions are often state positions with good benefits and fair salaries.
• There are a wide variety of positions throughout the campus.
cons:
There are times when administration is short sighted and do not have the vision needed to make wise decisions. Even when an industry consultant is employed and experienced staff warn of unfavorable decisions which could be detrimental to the services of the campus, they take the easy way out.
• Raises in salaries are tied to the state Budget and approval of the General Assembly.
• Position descriptions and salaries can have a wide range depending on departments.

review_title: UNC SOM is great, other departments not so much
job_title: Research Administrative in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Culture differs greatly between departments. My current one is great and is flexible with work hours and working from home (when need be). My immediate coworkers are great. Job security is strong due to state rules. Management in my particular department seems to really care about its employees (not the case in all departments)
cons: Pay is lower since it's a state organization and raises are hard to come by. Have to change departments frequently to get a raise. Though I work with a great team, many other people within the university are slow and disgruntled. Since it's very hard to get fired from a state position, some people don't try very hard. You have to pay for parking and then walk a good 15 minutes to your office.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chapel Hill, NC
pros:
- Great mentoring, support, and one-on-one time with my PI.
- Friendly people and beautiful campus.
- Countless opportunities for students to work in research labs.
cons:
- As a student, can be hard to find work on campus if you are not in the work-study program.
- Many PIs expect undergraduates to work for free.  Do not fall into this trap.  Apply for grants or find a boss willing to pay you.
- Money and politics are the primary factors in decision making.  If not surprising, it is certainly disheartening to see in a public institution of higher education.

review_title: Good job with sub-par compensation and benefits
job_title: IT Technician in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Great job with new and exciting challenges regularly. Ability to help others on a daily basis. Great culture and engaging work environment with many opportunities for learning and skill refinement.
cons: Compensation and benefits are lacking, and there isn't a clear-cut path for career-advancement. As a temp employee who is constantly going above and beyond and impressing upper management with my knowledge and skillset, I believe I am worth more to the university than I am currently making. However, I can;t seem to get a straight answer when I bring up my potential for future permanent full-time employment.

review_title: A great University with room to grow!
job_title: Business Officer in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: I love working at Chapel Hill. I truly enjoy helping our patients to achieve the type of care they hope for, and they've come to expect excellence at every visit.  Home to one of the premier Dental and Medical schools in the world, it is truly an honor to work for UNC.
cons:
Upward mobility it a major concern. The current state system makes it nearly impossible for employees to obtain raises or to move up in class. 
Diversity has been an issue for some time that is now being addressed, but there is a long road ahead.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Pay is better than nearby hospitals. The hospital has a great float pool of nurses and can normally help out our unit if we're short staffed. They have rapid response nurses who are so helpful even if you just want a second pair of eyes on a patient that is making you nervous. Shift differential pay is very high. I feel very supported as a nurse by the hospital and managers.
cons: Parking is definitely an issue. I have to pay over $200 a year and park three miles away to be shuttled in for day shift. The bus I take leaves at 6:15 am and it is very crowded. This makes for a long day when I'm already working a 12 hour shift.

review_title: Remember you are working for the state...
job_title: Marketing Manager in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Good healthcare, enjoyable fellow employees, good work/life balance (everyone leaves the office at 5:00), fun to work on a college campus, will pay for you to take classes at UNC or other NC school systems
cons: Terrible maternity leave policy (basically there is none, you either use vacation time or have to go on unpaid leave), no bonuses/incentives (in fact they don't even match the increase in cost of living every year), very politically-charged environment which can be overbearing at times, have to pay to park on campus and the cost of a permit is outrageous - $800-1,000/year

review_title: Interesting environment with lots to learn
job_title: Medical Diagnostic Technician in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Working around research means there's always something new to learn about. Culture is very low stress for staff; time off is almost always approved and mistakes, when made, are treated as learning experiences for everyone and not reprehensible offenses.
cons: Low pay for the position and mediocre benefits make it difficult to see UNC as a long-term place to work. The combined inertia of academia and government means that everything (HR, equipment acquisition, construction) moves very slowly.

review_title: Great opportunity to get a career started
job_title: Graduate Student in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Flexible hours with a structured work environment.  Working there is similar to employment as a state employee as they have all of the apparatus there to that "real" jobs have
cons: Commuting wasn't fun.  There is nowhere to park so your options are to drive to a park and ride, walk/bike or take the bus.  Truth told the park and rides are pretty efficient as is the bus system so you can't ask much more there.  That said it is much easier to drive to work when possible.

job_title: Research Technician in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Great learning environment that can help you excel in your career.
cons: Parking on campus is terrible, you probably will park 10-15 away from your building and during sporting events you will be kicked out of your spot or get fined or towed. Some HR departments are not very helpful when you have issues often times the employee is ignored completely.

review_title: A solid experience working with incredibly focused and talented students and talented caring faculty.
job_title: Marketing Director in Winston-Salem, NC
pros: To see the results of the efforts on behalf of the students as they go out into their careers and contribute to the positive arts and entertainment sectors that create better living environments for all of us.  The facilities are terrific for training and performances.  The involvement and support of the community in the school. The support of the students for each other and teamwork is wonderful.
cons: The artist as professional educator is a challenge for some of the faculty. Also, for the faculty balancing working as a professional and teaching has been an issue.

review_title: Satisfying Job which prepares you for a career in research
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Working with clinicians, doctors and other researchers from a non-statistical background helps you communicate your ideas and collaborate with them for statistical consultation. The hours vary depending on the time of the academic year but overall, it is not stressful and you learn a lot while writing research papers in collaboration with others.
cons: Sometimes around deadlines, the work can be stressful and the pay is just enough to maintain a basic standard of living.

review_title: Decent Job-Comfortable for Work-Family Life Balance
job_title: Project Manager in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Lots of autonomy and can dress very casually.  My position allows me to work from home occasionally and attend my children's school events.  Interesting and educated coworkers and I work in downtown Chapel Hill so there are lots of shops, restaurants and places to go for lunch.
cons: Salaries are so-so but due to the economy annual raises and few and far between.  Most of my work is grant-funded so I need to find a new position every few years when the current grant ends.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: There is a great teaching culture here, with a focus on continually improving teaching methods, and (for most professors) always being open to input on teaching methodology and style.
cons: The hours - they give a stipend for a certain number of expected hours per semester, and if you actually keep careful track of your hours it seems like you are punished by continually being given more work, while other students who are not as careful sort of fly under the radar and get away with not doing their requisite hours.

review_title: Not a good place to be
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Free bus. That's all I can think of.
cons:
Not enough support from university or faculty.
Financially, UNC has its own minimum salary and many PI just follow that.
Benefit wise, UNC always use the public excuse to justify why they offer subpar health insurance than Duke.
Postdoc office are especially disrespectful of the value of postdocs. Been through a session of public hearing when the postdoc office director freak out and asked the audience “whether you would argue with me about benefits or just do your job and get out of here”
UNC postdocs are classified into a category between student and faculty. Therefore, they don't qualify for any bebifites. 
When you are burning night oils in the lab, you will be surprised to learn that the janitors actually recive better benefits and qualify for pensions.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: The students were a pleasure to teach. The administration allowed me to develop the course without too much oversight. They acknowledged the positive teaching reviews. Peer reviews of teaching methods helped me improve.
cons: They pay did not change from the first semester to the last semester I taught. However, the NC government kept reducing the UNC system's budget during the same period. I expect the entire university system experienced the same problem. Parking was problematic but that is typical for any university. It would be nice if adjunct professors had access to parking closer in that they do today.

review_title: A word of advice for those considering the leap into Universities from Industry....
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: UNC Chapel Hill has a history of itegrity (we took a slight detour of late but only slight, the core is still solid) and teamwork.  We are all in this together.  The pace is quick enough to see progress but not so quick you need to see a doctor.  At the University it is what you know, not what you drive that defines you.  People are genuinely interested in you and your ideas.
cons: Universities are complex organisms.  Management is heavily dotted and matrixed.  At first, those coming into the Univ new may think, "why do they do that?" But, I promise that if you look closely you'll find there were very good reasons; those reasons may no longer be valid but the logic was sound.  We don't move quickly on anything.  Think of it as a very large steamship.  A correction made right now will only be seen a few miles down the way.  If you are one that wants to see immediate results, this may not be the place for you.  If you are in it for the long haul, you'll really enjoy it here.

job_title: Social Media Community Manager in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: UNC has great people who are very talented and fun to work with. The university environment gaurantees there is never a dull moment.
cons: The University is aware of the lack of diversity not only in its student body, but also in its faculty and staff and is constantly working to recruit a diversity of people.

job_title: Data Collection Specialist in Chapel Hill, NC
pros:
Work culture provided opportunities to meet prominent community figures who have helped me determine a more focused career path with an MSW.

Receptive to student employees,  paid attention to individual availability to maximize work hours offered.

Opportunity to work with middle and high school students providing qualitative and quantitative data compiled into report and comparison of needs (ie. gaps in services,  increase or decrease in juvenile violence or success rates).

Opportunity to work under a grant ultimately funded by CDC which is facing public health risk in the form of bullying and violence in schools.

Supportive of employee interests.  Such as my own in program development and involvement the process from data collection to resulting program modifications (such as exploring use of various intervention methods compatible with a rural at-risk juvenile population)

Experience working in the nonprofit sector.  Gain deeper understanding in the process of seeking grants in order to continue successful study and improvements in community programs such as teen court.  

Relevant to personal goals, provided professional experience in conmunity and individual needs assessment, paired well with graduate course work

These are the benefits.
cons:
As this is grant funded, nonprofit program, there are no benefits.

Communication and coordination between teams in the field (coverage of all public schools in two counties) could be challenging.

Might not meet everyone involved in the study face to face (main office in Raleigh). 

Not all educators are as cooperative as they would be if they were included more to understand the purpose of the study.

Schedule is based on when each school has a time slot to participate in the assessment.

Seasonal position, but could lead to aother more permanent role in the future.

Pay is not high, lots of early morning driving, not everyone you meet will value the project as much as you do but most are receptive to the goals of the longitudinal study.

review_title: P2P Department has very questionable personnel and management. Easy job if everybody worked.
job_title: P2P Driver in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Fair wages, but if you’re a temp there are no benefits offered. CDL required. Equipment maintained and up to standards. Uniforms.Get to work at UNC!
cons: No employee handbook nor orientation. No job descriptions provided.Management lacking in experience, people skills and don’t address issues in the department. Temps and night crew are looked down on. Lot of disgruntled employees. Literally no oversight of this dept.

review_title: This is actually a review for Kurama Express, but Glassdoor doesn't recognize it and I'd already written the review.
job_title: Food Prep, Cook, Server, Cashier in Chapel Hill, NC
pros:
Both customers and staff are laid-back and friendly. The base wage for servers is $4.50 an hour plus tips, so the money can be decent, especially during the school year when it's consistently busy. I averaged about $10, with a range between $8 and $14, but that was during the summer when business is slow. The restaurant is right beside UNC campus, so this is a good job for students.

The job is not super demanding, beyond the basic act of standing a lot. Management is willing to work around class schedules and travel.
cons:
The business desperately needs a technology upgrade, as schedules are posted on paper the day before the week starts. You have to call and have a coworker read it to you. It can be difficult to arrange personal plans on such short notice. 

Training is subpar and disorganized. The main method is "watch," which works for some people, but not everyone. I can't count the number of times no one thought to tell me a thing until after I had done it incorrectly. Like soft-shell crab can explode in a fountain of boiling oil due to its high water content, so don't stand close to the fryer.

Management has been beaten down by years of overwork and has therefore let some quality slide. Employees--kitchen staff especially--spend time on their phones instead of working. The kitchen desperately needs a deep cleaning of the walls and appliances after many years of a exposure to a fryer. (Although food preparation surfaces are cleaned regularly.)

Most concerning is that employees are not taught proper food safety. I have seen employees take a paper towel out of the trash and wipe food preparation surfaces with it, touch the floor with an implement and then hang it up without washing it, and drop food on the floor.

review_title: UNC is a Victim of State Budget Cuts
job_title: IT Analyst in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Numerous Departments have lots of great hard working people working for them.  It's a great place to start your career and gain experience in lower level positions.  Leadership for the most part is great depending on the Department.  The Bus system is efficient.  If you are in a well managed Department you will have more flexible hours and a good number of managers are great to work for which results in higher motivation and more productivity among staff.
cons:
Unfortunately once you've gained your experience in order to be compensated for your market value you have to apply for and accept positions in other Departments due to state funding being cut from the University so much for so long.  This often results in brain drain as Departments end up with no continuity as their more knowledgeable / valuable employees end up leaving / working elsewhere for higher pay.  Funding has consistently declined since 2009.  As a result it has created an environment were there are pockets or groups that fear they will be the next layoff and as a result are afraid to share knowledge to help UNC grow which as a result leads to various teams not working together to resolve issues.    The budget decline can be managed well with the right people in place but in a smaller percentage of departments poor leadership style or management results in wanting to blame a decline in services on individual employee productivity when in fact it is simply a result of declining resources. 

 A large part of the buildings / infrastructure are in disrepair / poor upkeep due to lack of funding and mismanagement (there are instances of air conditioning and heating running in older buildings at the same time) while new buildings are constantly being built.  Parking is a disaster due to lack of planning (typically they love building new buildings but down't plan adequate parking along with it).  Some management styles are to lead by fear when faced by shrinking budgets which results in low moral, lost productivity, and passing the buck or blame for issues so the speak by other employees as they fear being singled out as the reason an issue occurred when in most cases the issue was created by poor Departmental policy.  

The overall climate with the State budget has forced UNC to make some tough decisions that have often resulted in colleagues you become close with leaving for better opportunities.  Great to start a career and learn if you are willing to work low wages but once you gain experience / knowledge and your market value is worth so much more on the private sector factors in the local economy all but force you to take advantage of them even if you value the academic mission of the University it is resulting in a larger churn and turnover.

review_title: Great place to work, but very slow pace
job_title: Software Engineer in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Great college town, lots of opportunity to succeed, very few to fail
cons: It is almost impossible to get anything done here because of the bureaucracy. I once waited 6 months, and burned over $30,000, waiting on a laptop that the school would not approve because it didn't come from an "approved vendor" (I needed a special laptop with a GPU). The laptop cost $2000.

review_title: Carolina - a great university and place to work
job_title: Assistant Dean in Chapel Hill, NC
pros:
** dedicated peers and colleagues, wiling to share knowledge and collaborate across departmental lines
** flexible schedules (depending on supervisor)
** strong belief in employee professional development and career growth
** good pay and decent (not great) benefits
** an opportunity to serve the public and the state of NC
cons:
** budgets are tight
** much-needed change to various business processes and systems can come very SLOWLY
** communications between units can be poor

job_title: Assistant Director in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Vibrant place to work with great benefits. Enjoyed working with the students.
cons: High stress, limited upward mobility once you are in your position.

review_title: A great IT community with the perils of working for the state
job_title: Desktop Computing Analyst in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Great IT community, solid infrastructure, decent salary.
cons: Parking is a nightmare (park and ride is often the only option for those without state service). UNC-CH is part of the UNC system, which has high leadership turnover and a fractious relationship with the legislature. This makes handling crises like COVID-19 difficult.

review_title: Great pay for temps, not a lot of opportunity for permanent
job_title: Administrative Assistant in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Applies to temp employees...Pay was great. Access to free seminars, courses, etc. Good support in many departments. Travel per diem was excellent. Diverse environment. Many departments are open minded to multicultural differences.
cons: Applies to temp employees only. Hired as temp with promise of perm position that was given to current permanent employee. This happened to a number of employees I knew. Required to take 30 day leave every year. Health benefits are not affordable even for bare minimum. No paid time off.

review_title: It is  a comfortable place to work.
job_title: Adiministrative Support Specialist in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Lovely campus.  Intelligent colleagues, good working environment.  Some flexibility and pretty good benefits and retirement.
cons: Academic snobbery, limited advancement for staff, salaries are not competitive with other universities or private industry.  you get pigeon-holed in a certain type of job.

review_title: A great environment to develop professional skills
job_title: Resident Advisor in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Being a Resident Advisor at UNC is a great addition to any resume--you learn interpersonal skills, conflict resolution, crisis management, etc. The compensation is above average and there are a lot of perks.
cons:
You have to be proactive about maintaining a work/life balance in a job like this. 
Like any job, your experience depends heavily on how well you mesh with your supervisor.
Other RAs can be a lot if you have a more reserved personality.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: I have held two separate positions at UNC in two separate departments and both of which taught me practical skills that would otherwise be impossible for someone to find with my age and level of education. UNC treats you like a professional in whatever avenue you choose which helps you to hone your abilities and become more employable after you enter the working world.
cons: Although the jobs offered are educationally and vocationally enriching, most are through the work-study department which only offers employment while class is in session.

review_title: UNC is a good place to work
job_title: Program Coordinator in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: There is a lot of amazing scientific research being done at UNC-CH and it feels great to be part of work that is helping to cure and manage diseases around the world.
cons: As with probably any large organization it can be frustratingly bureaucratic at times. You usually need to change jobs to get a raise as opposed to being rewarded for doing a good job over time.

review_title: Good place to work, but little room for growth
job_title: Manager of Marketing in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Working for the university and state means you have a ton of connections, work is fun and fulfilling, and also you never need to work more than 40 hours a week. After a year long probationary period, you are protected. The success of the job is very dependent on your supervisor.
cons: Promotions and raises are heavily regulated by the state and not easy to come by.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Non-management and working with other departments is easy.
cons: Deductibles in health insurance and being price gouged for parking. Nepotism is a big problem. Academics do not like being told they are wrong in spite of overwhelming evidence. Promotions are not based on merit, but rather on affirmative action policies. You are expected to work long hours and perform four jobs in one role. High turnover rate.

job_title: Research Study Coordinator in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Some pros include generous vacation/sick time/ holidays, flexible hours (depending on supervisor), benefits (health insurance, dental insurance), and a generally nice working environment.
cons: The biggest con is the salary range. This is lower compared to private companies which is to be expected, and is not that bad when considering the other pros.

review_title: School of Medicine Temp to permanent worker
job_title: Accounting Processor in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Decent coworkers, good work life balance, Good working environments
cons: had to pay for parking, few hours, little communication between self and management

job_title: Lecturer in Chapel Hill, NC

cons: Of course as an adjunct, my own research was not supported in the least. I couldn't get the department chip in anything at all when I was presenting at a conference.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chapel Hill, NC
pros:
Students are great - smart, driven, fun, interesting. 
Campus is gorgeous
Low- & mid-level staff are smart and committed to supporting students
Faculty are also smart & committed to their students
cons:
Major loss in financial and institutional support from the legislators in Raleigh.
Two small raises in 5 years

job_title: Associate Dean in Chapel Hill, NC

Pay raises for staff are few and far between, even for EPA administrators (virtually non-existent for SPA staff). It's a very difficult environment for supervisors because opportunities to reward excellent employees are limited, and it's nearly impossible to fire slackers.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Chapel Hill, NC

job_title: Research Technician I in Chapel Hill, NC

review_title: It has been a wonderful, yet complicated journey.
job_title: Credentialed Medical Assistant in Smithfield, NC
pros: The patients and certain providers will always keep a smile on anyone’s face.
cons: The workload, and some of the staff are not the best people. Just be careful.

review_title: Great Graduate Student Salary, Benefits, and Student Support
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Very competitive stipend, especially for cost of living in the Triangle. Incrimental raises (~$50-$100 each year) based on inflations and cost of tuition,
cons: The university tends to deem graduate students as students when it is convenient for them and employees when it is convenient for them. For example, graduate students are considered students when it comes to investing into UNC portfolios i.e. students are not allowed to buy in.

job_title: Resident Advisor in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: The people are nice and fun to work with, the emphasis on cultural values are positive but administration can go a bit overboard at times, overall an excellent experience
cons: Work life balance suffered slightly. Once your in the system its easy to work long hours and get sucked into the job without regard for your personal time. As mentioned before administration can sometimes go overboard on emphasizing diversity and cultural equality

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: Academic environments are more collaborative that some other work environments. Depending on your field, there are opportunities for other positions within the university and for professional growth. There are opportunities for interesting work for self starters willing to work their way up, and depending on field of expertise.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Chapel Hill, NC
pros:
Very positive and welcoming environment
Students are really bright, even if a little entitled-acting
cons: Very clear that you are at the bottom of the totem pole. A lot of favoritism exhibited, and definitely not a meritocracy.

review_title: The learning experience is not limited only to education but a peek into life as a whole.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Chapel Hill, NC
pros: There are opportunities galore and connections/bonds to be made.
cons: There are many sidetracking temptations. However, whether they are temptations of additional opportunities is up to the individual.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Chapel Hill, NC

The office hour of International Scholar Office is very limited,  and it may take several months to get feedback if you send an request to their office email address (although some of the staff are extremely friendly and eager to help). review_title: Great institution to advance your research career as a postdoc

review_title: Good place to work- must create your own space

review_title: With effort comes reward at UNC-Chapel Hill

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Chapel Hill, NC

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Chapel Hill, NC

review_title: The view from Public Health: You take the good, you take the bad...

review_title: World-class organization that needs to be more innovative
